Analysis & Case Selection
page (

) Purpose: This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) contains speciﬁc information the workload identiﬁcation method that is in use by the IRS to identify and select tax returns for Automated Underreporter (AUR), Business (BUR) and Affordable Care Act (ACA), which includes both Employer Shared Responsibility Payment (ESRP) and Non-ﬁler. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to employees working in SB/SE, Exam Case Selection, Document Matching, Analysis & Case Selection (DMACS). (
) Policy Owner: SB/SE Director, Exam Headquarters is the policy owner. (
) Program Owner: SB/SE, Exam Case Selection, is the program owner sible for the administration, procedures and updates related to DMACS. (

) SB/SE Program Level Objective: Ensure examinations are initiated based indicators of non-compliance or on other criteria (such as selection for the National Research Program), identiﬁed in the Internal Revenue Manual. In addition, ensure a review of the decisions to survey a return (i.e., not initiate an examination) are based upon factors outlined in the Internal Revenue Manual and approved by an appropriate level of management. Note: While AUR, BUR and ACA notices are not audits, but are considered taxpayer contacts per Rev. Proc.
, the overall selection principles addressed in the language above apply. (
) DMACS Program Objective: The objective of DMACS is to identify, select deliver inventory for the AUR, BUR and ACA document matching programs within the campuses. (

) Underreporter cases are built from two primary sources: • The Master File (MF) contains information reported to the IRS by taxpayers. This includes current entity information, tax account, and tax returns. • The Information Return Master File (IRMF) contains information submitted by payers. (
) The IMF ﬁle contains information reported on: • Form
, U.S. Individual Income Tax Return • Form
NR, U.S. Nonresident Alien Income Tax Return • Form
SR, U.S. Income Tax Return for Seniors • For TY
and prior, Form
A, U.S. Individual Income Tax • For TY
and prior, Form
EZ, Income Tax Return for Single Joint Filers with No Dependents (
) The BMF ﬁle contains information reported on: • Form
, U.S. Corporation Income Tax Return • Form
, U.S. Income Tax Return for Estates and Trusts • Form
, U.S. Return of Partnership Income • Form
S, U.S. Income Tax Return for an S Corporation (

) The IRMF information is matched with the IMF and BMF tax returns to verify certain income, deductions and credits, that can be supported by information returns, are properly reported on the tax return. An AUR or BUR case is

) The Director of Exam Case Selection (ECS) is responsible for providing guidance on the selection of cases and delivery of inventory for SB/SE nation, including AUR, BUR and ACA. (

) The DMACS Program Manager is responsible for: a. Establishing internal controls relating to each program or process. b. Ensuring that instructions are communicated and carried out by the assigned employees. c. Sets policy, establishes procedures and guidelines and ensures they applied consistently. d. Revises policies as required and redesigns processes as necessary resulting from legislative changes. e. Performs managerial reviews of selection decisions during each the selection and delivery process. f. Reviews and approves the business requirements written for case selection and Uniform Work Requests (UWRs) annually. g. Provides input into the AUR, BUR and ACA work plans. h. Provides input to the SB/SE Division Strategic Plan. (

) DMACS analysts are responsible for: a. Selection and delivery of AUR, BUR and ACA inventory multiple times per year. b. Monitor results and perform analytics to improve selection. c. Provide campus support and guidance on workload selection and delivery-related issues. d. Work collaboratively with Performance Planning & Analysis (PPA) to develop annual workload plans. (
) The Director of ECS (or designee) ensures that the DMACS Program reviews adhere to case selection policy. (
) Managerial reviews of selection decisions occur during each phase of the selection and delivery process. (

Planning and Special

) To achieve the workplan volumes, DMACS analysts consider the following factors during the case selection process: • Issue coverage • Revenue protection • Taxpayer burden • Inﬂuence taxpayer behavior (repeaters) • Prior document matching case results (including “agreed” and “no change” rates) • Fairness and integrity • Available resources • Level of automation • Reliability of data sources • Taxpayer Bill of Rights (

) SB/SE supports administration of tax law by selecting returns to audit. The primary objective in selecting returns for examination is to promote the degree of voluntary compliance on the part of taxpayers while making the efficient use of ﬁnite examination staffing and other resources. Employees must exercise their professional judgment, not personal opinions, when return selection decisions. As explained in Policy Statement

, IRS employees are expected to carry out our duties with integrity and fairness. • To ensure fairness to the taxpaying public, our Examination Workplan provides a balanced approach for return delivery and allocation of resources to address areas of the Tax Gap by taking into account factors such as income levels, geographic locations, and return types. • To ensure an equitable process for all taxpayers, return selection decisions are made utilizing available experience and/or statistics indi- cating the probability of substantial error. No one individual can control the examination selection decision- making process. We limit involve- ment to only those employees whose duties require them to be included.

To ensure fairness to the taxpaying public, our Examination Workplan provides a balanced approach for return delivery and allocation of resources to address areas of the Tax Gap by taking into account factors such as income levels, geographic locations, and return types. To ensure an equitable process for all taxpayers, return selection decisions are made utilizing available experience and/or statistics indi
cating the probability of substantial error. No one individual can control the examination selection decision
making process. We limit involve
ment to only those employees whose duties require them to be included.
Matching, Analysis & Case Selection 4.1.27
PPA determines the number of cases that need to be selected for program. DMACS analysts use the following to ﬁll those numbers.

Case selection for AUR and BUR begins with a set of business requirements that are used to deﬁne when a case is brought into correlation for potential selection. These business requirements deﬁne aspects of the tax returns to be matched to the respective information returns received. When discrepancies arise, the case is created for potential selection.

Requirements for correlation are reviewed by the program analysts an annual basis to ensure effectiveness and relevance. New tax forms, legislation and line changes are identiﬁed and to reﬂect the speciﬁc tax year. Drop criteria, data elements of speciﬁc entity, tax returns, and tion returns, are incorporated in the correlation requirements and are reviewed annually to determine if modiﬁcations are needed. Requirements are reviewed and Uniform Work Requests (UWRs) are approved by the Program Manager of DMACS annually.
Note: Although the DMACS analysts are responsible for providing requirements, the actual correlation process is done by the corresponding Information Technologies (IT) functions.
4.1 Planning and Special Programs

) Case selection for ESRP begins with a set of business requirements that are used to deﬁne when a case is brought into correlation for potential selection. These business requirements deﬁne aspects of the tax returns to be to the respective information returns received. When a potential payment the case is created for potential selection. • Requirements for correlation are reviewed by the program analysts on an annual basis to ensure effectiveness and relevance. • New tax forms, legislation and line changes are identiﬁed and to reﬂect the speciﬁc tax year. • Drop criteria, data elements of speciﬁc entity, tax returns, and tion returns, are incorporated in the correlation requirements and are reviewed annually to determine if modiﬁcations are needed. Note: Although the Employment Tax Policy analysts are responsible providing requirements, the actual correlation process is done the corresponding Information Technologies (IT) functions. (
) The workload identiﬁcation for ACA Non-Filer begins with taxpayers that appear to have Form

-C ﬁling requirement and no associated return. • Requirements for correlation are reviewed by the program analysts on an annual basis to ensure effectiveness and relevance. • New tax forms, legislation and line changes are identiﬁed and to reﬂect the speciﬁc tax year. • Drop criteria, data elements of speciﬁc entity, tax returns, and tion returns, are incorporated in the correlation requirements and are reviewed annually to determine if modiﬁcations are needed. (
) DMACS analysts obtain a raw list of potential non-ﬁlers from Compliance Warehouse (CDW). Potential non-ﬁlers consist of identifying Applicable Employers (ALE) who have not ﬁled the required Forms
-C. • Employers with
or more full-time employees (including full-time equivalent employees) in the previous year. • Research is done based on the preceding year W-

) Each AUR and BUR case is stratiﬁed based on the main underreported and identifying traits. To segment the population, cases are assigned the following three deﬁners: • Category: This is a two-digit numeric code that describes the primary discrepant issue on the taxpayer’s return. The code is set based on tablished criteria such as the percentage of the discrepancy that must be achieved in order for the case to be designated in a particular category. Each case is assigned one category code. See Exhibit
and Exhibit

for a list of AUR and BUR categories. • Subﬁle: This is a one-character alphanumeric code that describes reporting attributes of a case or taxpayer. The subﬁle designation is typically a compliance attribute. Examples include information types, speciﬁc return attributes, or compliance behavior such as a repeater. The code is assigned in a priority order, so each case is only one subﬁle code. See Exhibit
and Exhibit
for a list AUR and BUR subﬁles.

Case selection for ESRP begins with a set of business requirements that are used to deﬁne when a case is brought into correlation for potential selection. These business requirements deﬁne aspects of the tax returns to be matched to the respective information returns received. When a potential payment the case is created for potential selection.

Requirements for correlation are reviewed by the program analysts on an annual basis to ensure effectiveness and relevance. New tax forms, legislation and line changes are identiﬁed and updated to reﬂect the speciﬁc tax year. Drop criteria, data elements of speciﬁc entity, tax returns, and informa
tion returns, are incorporated in the correlation requirements and are reviewed annually to determine if modiﬁcations are needed.
Note: Although the Employment Tax Policy analysts are responsible for providing requirements, the actual correlation process is done by the corresponding Information Technologies (IT) functions.
The workload identiﬁcation for ACA Non-Filer begins with taxpayers that appear to have Form 1094-C ﬁling requirement and no associated return.
Requirements for correlation are reviewed by the program analysts on an annual basis to ensure effectiveness and relevance.
New tax forms, legislation and line changes are identiﬁed and to reﬂect the speciﬁc tax year.
Drop criteria, data elements of speciﬁc entity, tax returns, and tion returns, are incorporated in the correlation requirements and are reviewed annually to determine if modiﬁcations are needed.

The code is set based on tablished criteria such as the percentage of the discrepancy that must be achieved in order for the case to be designated in a particular category. Each case is assigned one category code. See Exhibit

The subﬁle designation is typically a compliance attribute. Examples include information types, speciﬁc return attributes, or compliance behavior such as a repeater. Matching, Analysis & Case Selection 4.1.27

• Subcategory: A one-character alpha code that describes the range of the potential tax change attributed to the discrepancy. If the tax falls within a speciﬁed range, then the subcategory is set. The code is determined based on a discrete range, so each case is only assigned one subcategory code. See Exhibit
and Exhibit
for a list of AUR and BUR subcategories. (

for a list of Non-ﬁler Categories. (
) Implementation of the Information Return Document Matching (IRDM) encompasses multiple systems:
Data Assimilation: Assimilation identiﬁes the link between tax forms information returns ﬁled for the same taxpayer.

Data Correlation: Correlation compares tax return and information data and applies business rules to identify potential underreporter After case selection, data correlation builds a complete case record to worked by a tax examiner. Note: Data Assimilation and Data Correlation are IT functions.

Two analytic systems provide DMACS analysts with the ability to deﬁne and execute logic for the intelligent selection of inventory to ensure effective case selection. • Case Identiﬁcation, Selection and Analysis (CISA) • Business Master File Analytics (BMFA) (
) Implementation of the Affordable Care Act encompasses multiple systems. ESRP:
Data Assimilation- Assimilation identiﬁes the link between tax forms applicable large employers (ALE’s) and employees that have claimed a premium tax credit (PTC)

Data Correlation- Correlation compares tax return data for an ALE employee return data and applies business rules to identify potential ESRP cases. Note: Data Assimilation and Data Correlation are IT Functions.

Subcategory: A one-character alpha code that describes the range of the potential tax change attributed to the discrepancy. If the tax falls within a speciﬁed range, then the subcategory is set. The code is determined based on a discrete range, so each case is only assigned one subcategory code. See Exhibit 4.1.27-4 and Exhibit 4.1.27-8 for a list of AUR and BUR subcategories.

) Implementation of the Affordable Care Act encompasses multiple systems. For ESRP:
Data Assimilation- Assimilation identiﬁes the link between tax forms for applicable large employers (ALE’s) and employees that have claimed a premium tax credit (PTC)
Data Correlation- Correlation compares tax return data for an ALE and employee return data and applies business rules to identify potential ESRP cases.

Note: Data Assimilation and Data Correlation are IT Functions.
Data Assimilation- Assimilation identiﬁes potential non-ﬁler cases for applicable large employers (ALE’s).
Data Correlation- Correlation compares a potential ALE employee and applies business rules to identify potential non-ﬁler cases.
Note: Data Assimilation and Data Correlation are manual and completed by DMACS analysts.
4.1 Planning and Special Programs

) DMACS uses the Information Return Document Matching Case Inventory Selection and Analysis (IRDMCISA) tool to select cases for AUR to work. The tool’s web-based user interface provides easy access to features and function- Analysis ality and requires no technical programming knowledge to operate from the interface. The tool includes many user-requested features and capabilities, and it allows users to import, score, analyze, and select cases to work. (

) CISA provides DMACS analysts with the ability to deﬁne and execute logic for the intelligent selection of individual taxpayer case inventory. By comparing cases in the current correlation to similar cases from past correlations, the tool’s capabilities include the following:
Assign each case an Estimated Potential Assessment (EPA) score. (
) DMACS analysts conduct case selection by selecting the optimal mix of under- reporting cases to pursue. An optimal mix of cases includes cases that address the following. See IRM
for the full list. • Revenue protection. • Inﬂuence taxpayer behavior (repeaters). • Ensure fair coverage of all taxpayer segments. (
) The selection of cases is limited to three times per year. These periods of intense selection activities are known as correlation cycles and are based on tax reporting deadlines. (

) DMACS staff analyzes results, performs program reviews, and monitors rule- based applications used to select inventory. The results are used to make data-driven decisions to improve program quality, improve case selection, and ensure the integrity of the selection methods. (
) Selection is the process of identifying the optimal mix of cases to be worked in the AUR Program. The process occurs in eight phases described below:
Data Import: Importing the data into the CISA Tool.

Data Checks: Methods for ensuring the data was received and calcu- lated correctly, including volume, calculation data quality, and ﬁeld population checks. Note: The Data Integrity Failure Report is located in the Miscellaneous Reporting section of the tool.

Scoring: The tool scores the cases by assigning an EPA and a repeater code to each case. Users update the assessment rate table before the ﬁrst correlation to ensure that the scoring is as accurate as possible.

Business Rules: The user builds business rules, runs the selection tool and reviews the selected inventory. After business rules are complete, cases are generally selected by the highest EPA amount. Rules apply treatment codes to individual cases. See Exhibit
Treatment Code, for selection and non-selection of cases. The treatment also identi- ﬁes if the case will be available in subsequent correlations for selection consideration.

Optimization: The cases are optimized by subﬁle using one of three methods: No Moving, Balance by BOD, and Corporate Balance. The opti- mization function allows the workload to be balanced among campuses using the highest EPA in each subﬁle. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Selection is the process of identifying the optimal mix of cases to be worked in the AUR Program. The process occurs in eight phases described below:

Scoring: The tool scores the cases by assigning an EPA and a repeater code to each case. Users update the assessment rate table before the ﬁrst correlation to ensure that the scoring is as accurate as possible.

Business Rules: The user builds business rules, runs the selection tool and reviews the selected inventory. After business rules are complete, cases are generally selected by the highest EPA amount. Rules apply treatment codes to individual cases. See Exhibit
Treatment Code, for selection and non-selection of cases. The treatment also ﬁes if the case will be available in subsequent correlations for selection consideration.

Optimization: The cases are optimized by subﬁle using one of three methods: No Moving, Balance by BOD, and Corporate Balance. The mization function allows the workload to be balanced among campuses using the highest EPA in each subﬁle.

These reports can be viewed after correlation.
total EPA for cases selected, average EPA for cases selected, number cases selected, and other statistics. These reports can be viewed after correlation. (

) The Business Master File Analytics (BMFA) system is the tool used for BUR case selection. BMFA is a web-based application that allows a user to drill- down from parent tabs through multiple subtabs. Users have the option to the integrity of data, build rules to select cases, export data, and view reports. (
) BMFA provides DMACS analysts with the ability to deﬁne and execute logic the intelligent selection of business taxpayer case inventory. (
) DMACS analysts conduct case selection, a process of selecting the optimal mix of underreporting cases to pursue. An optimal mix of cases include that address the following. See IRM
for the full list. • Revenue protection. • Inﬂuence taxpayer behavior (repeaters). • Ensure fair coverage of all taxpayer segments. (

) The selection of cases is limited to two or three times per year dependent on the workplan. These periods of intense selection activities are called correla- tion cycles and are based on tax reporting deadlines. (

) DMACS staff analyze results, perform program reviews, and monitor rule- based applications used to select inventory. The results are used to make data-based decisions to improve program quality, improve case selection, to ensure the integrity of the selection methods. (
) Selection is the act of identifying the optimal mix of cases to be delivered to the BUR campus. The process occurs in six phases:
Data Import: Importing the data into the Case Selection (BMFA) Tool.
Data Checks: Data Checks are methods for ensuring the data was received correctly, including volume, calculation data quality, data ﬁeld, and ﬁeld population checks.
Analysis: Review prior year results manually to readdress business based on results.
Business Rules: Build business rules, run the selection tool and view the selected inventory.
Reports: View reports that reﬂect volumes and average EPA for cases, and other statistics.
Export: Export cases to the campus. Inventory is assigned a cycle utilizing a schedule that ensures it will meet the start plan date to conform to the annual work plan.
Data Import: Importing the data into the Case Selection (BMFA) Tool.
Data Checks: Data Checks are methods for ensuring the data was received correctly, including volume, calculation data quality, data ﬁeld, and ﬁeld population checks.
Analysis: Review prior year results manually to readdress business based on results.
Business Rules: Build business rules, run the selection tool and view the selected inventory.
Reports: View reports that reﬂect volumes and average EPA for cases, and other statistics.
Export: Export cases to the campus. Inventory is assigned a cycle utilizing a schedule that ensures it will meet the start plan date to conform to the annual work plan.
4.1 Planning and Special

) After each correlation, a Summary Report is prepared by DMACS case selection analysts. This manual report documents the selection activities for the respective underreporter program, including executed business rules each correlation. The summary addresses: • The correlation activities, including case volumes impacted by non-selection and global non-select business rules. • Business justiﬁcation for each rule, the SQL language or formula for the rule, any number limitations applied to the rule, the last date rule was run and the total cases impacted by each rule. Include as to selected inventory, including volumes by category, subﬁle and categories. • Documentation used and any analysis performed during the process. (
) The DMACS program manager is required to review and approve the summary after each correlation prior to the export process. (

) DMACS uses the Employer Shared Responsibility Payment System (ESRP System) to select cases for ESRP to work. The ESRP System is a application that allows users to import, apply ﬁlters, analyze, and select to be built into batches. (
) The ESRP System provides DMACS analysts with the ability to deﬁne and execute logic for the intelligent selection of ESRP inventory. (
) DMACS analysts conduct case selection, a process of selecting the optimal mix of cases to pursue. An optimal mix of cases include cases that address the following. See IRM
for the full list. • Revenue protection. • Inﬂuence taxpayer behavior (repeaters). • Ensure fair coverage of all taxpayer segments. (
) The selection of cases is currently limited to once a year. (

) DMACS staff analyze results, perform program reviews, and monitor rule- based applications used to select inventory. The results are used to make data-based decisions to improve program quality, improve case selection, to ensure the integrity of the selection methods. (
) Selection is the act of identifying the optimal mix of cases to be delivered the ESRP campus. The process occurs in six phases:
Download Data: Download reports from Business Objects Created ACA Compliance Validation (ACV).
Data Import: Importing the data into the ESRP System Tool.

After each correlation, a Summary Report is prepared by DMACS case selection analysts. This manual report documents the selection activities for the respective underreporter program, including executed business rules for each correlation. The summary addresses:
The correlation activities, including case volumes impacted by selection, non
selection and global non
select business rules.

Business justiﬁcation for each rule, the SQL language or formula written for the rule, any number limitations applied to the rule, the last date the rule was run and the total cases impacted by each rule. Include details as to selected inventory, including volumes by category, subﬁle and sub
categories.
Documentation used and any analysis performed during the selection process.
The DMACS program manager is required to review and approve the selection summary after each correlation prior to the export process.
The ESRP System provides DMACS analysts with the ability to deﬁne and execute logic for the intelligent selection of ESRP inventory.
Matching, Analysis & Case Selection 4.1.27

Data Checks: Data Checks are automated checks done during import ensure the data was received correctly, including volume, calculation quality, data ﬁeld, and ﬁeld population checks. GII Case Information: GII is used to do an EITCRA run to pull case formation from IDRS including the Employment code and Business Operating Division (BOD) code. Analysis: Review prior year results manually to readdress business based on results. Filters: Filters are applied to the workable inventory to get counts and view the selected inventory. Reports: View reports that reﬂect volumes and proﬁle of selected and other statistics. Batch Building: Cases are built into batches for issuance of the

and other statistics.
Batch Building: Cases are built into batches for issuance of the

J, printed and mailed by the Office of Taxpayer Correspondence (OTC). Inventory is assigned a batch utilizing a schedule that ensures will meet the start plan date to conform to the annual work plan. DMACS uses SAS (a data analytics tool) to run SQL programming and an Access Database to select cases for ESRP to work. This is a manual that identiﬁes cases and allows users to import, apply ﬁlters, analyze, and select cases to be built into batches. DMACS will use the list to establish selection criteria and prioritize the information return non-ﬁler cases. DMACS analysts conduct case selection, a process of selecting the optimal mix of non-ﬁler cases to pursue. An optimal mix of cases include cases that address the following. See IRM

for the full list. • Revenue protection. • Inﬂuence taxpayer behavior (repeaters). • Ensure fair coverage of all taxpayer segments The selection of cases is currently limited to once a year. DMACS staff analyze results, perform program reviews, and monitor rule- based applications used to select inventory. The results are used to make data-based decisions to improve program quality, improve case selection, to ensure the integrity of the selection methods. Selection is the act of identifying the optimal mix of cases to be delivered to the ESRP campus. The process occurs in six phases:
Download Data: Download reports created in SAS.
Data Import: Importing the data into an Access Database.
Data Checks: Data Checks are automated checks done during import ensure the data was received correctly, including volume, calculation quality, data ﬁeld, and ﬁeld population checks.
Analysis: Review prior year results manually to readdress business based on results.
Filters: Filters are applied to the workable inventory to get counts and view the selected inventory.
Reports: View reports that reﬂect volumes and proﬁle of selected and other statistics.
Batch Building: Cases are built into batches for issuance of the
, weekly batches are sent to the OTC to be printed and mailed.

4.1 Planning and Special Programs

) After each correlation, a Summary Report is prepared by DMACS case selection analysts. This manual report documents the selection activities for the respective program, including ﬁlters applied for each correlation. The summary addresses: • The correlation activities, including case volumes impacted by selection and selection and non-selection criteria applied. • Business justiﬁcation for criteria applied and details as to selected inventory, including volumes by category. • Documentation used and any analysis performed during the selection process. ) Most of the workload delivery is systemic. Cases identiﬁed for data sharing manually extracted and delivered in the ﬁle format preferred by recipient. Process (
) All of the workload delivery is systemic. Inventory which has been selected for opening in each campus operation will be created on the AUR system. Workload Delivery (

) AUR cases are worked by seven campuses. Each campus’s inventory is composed of electronic (ELF) and paper cases. a. The capacity at each campus is established based on the campus work plan prepared by PPA. The CISA tool determines the minimum EPA inventory required to meet the campus combined capacity (i.e., capacity). b. ELF cases with higher EPA than the capacity to be worked are moved another campus with the capacity to work the cases. c. Paper and ELF cases are distributed equally between the campuses. (

) Optimization is the movement of cases to ensure each campus has the volume and quality of cases. There are three types of optimization that the CISA tool can produce within each individual subﬁle: • No Moving: Cases are already assigned an AUR campus based on geographic location of the taxpayer. The No Moving function allows the tool user to designate a minimum EPA threshold. • Balance by BOD: Previously used to balance inventory between the legacy W&I and SBSE campuses.

Planning and Special (

) DMACS shares IMF and BMF underreporter data with other functions for pliance consideration. Generally, the shared data is outside the scope of AUR and BUR Campus environments or the underreporter issue is too complex. The underreporter data contains ﬁled income tax returns and information returns. The type of data shared is based on the criteria between DMACS and the requesting function. The criteria may change year to year. Common data points include underreported data, categories, categories and subﬁles. (

) During AUR case selection, segments of cases can be identiﬁed for with other compliance programs based on the criteria requested. Rules are written to mark cases with the EXM treatment code based on the criteria agreement. The cases identiﬁed to be shared are excluded from the AUR selection process and not considered in the selection for regular inventory. IRDMCISA generates a TIN listing to be shared along with other necessary case data, which is provided to the requestor of the information. Example: An example of AUR data sharing is after DMACS selected TY
inventory for the AUR program, an extract ﬁle was provided to ECS- Campus Case Selection (CCS) using the remaining Form
underreporter data with treatment code ‘Global Non-Select’ (GNS). Based on the criteria agreement, DMACS limited the data to include crepant cases with over
information related returns within income categories and subﬁles. (

) During BUR case selection, segments of cases can be identiﬁed for with other compliance programs based on the criteria requested. Rules are written to mark cases with the treatment code EXM based on the criteria agreement. The cases identiﬁed to be shared are excluded from the BUR selection process and not considered in the selection for regular BUR inventory. IRDMBMFA generates a TIN listing to be shared with other necessary case data, which is provided to the requestor of the information.

CATEGORY NAME DESCRIPTION 04 Non-Employee Compensa- Gross Receipts is at least 50% of the discrepancy, and tion there is a Non-Employee Compensation IR with no other IR Amounts related to Gross Receipts. 12 Interest and Dividends Interest and Dividends are at least 50% of the amount of the total case discrepancy. 10 Interest Interest is at least 50% of the amount of the total case discrepancy. 11 Dividends Dividends is at least 50% of the amount of the total case discrepancy. 40 Capital Gains Capital Gains is the largest amount of the total case discrepancy. 31 Securities Security Sales is the largest amount of the total case discrepancy. 17 Fishing Gross Receipts is at least 50% of the discrepancy, and there is a Fishing IR with no other IR Amounts related to Gross Receipts. 18 Rents Rents is at least 50% of the amount of the total case discrepancy. 19 Royalties Royalties is at least 50% of the amount of the total case discrepancy. 20 Farming Farming Income is at least 50% of the amount of the discrepancy. 21 Medical Payments Gross Receipts is at least 50% of the discrepancy and there is a Medical Payments IR with no other IR Amounts related to Gross Receipts. 22 Positive Distributive Share Positive Distributive Share Income is at least 50% of Income the amount of the discrepancy. 27 Misc Other Income Other Income is at least 50% of the discrepancy and Misc Other Income is the only IR for that line. 43 Bartering Gross Receipts is at least 50% of the discrepancy, and there is a Bartering IR with no other IR Amounts related to Gross Receipts. 48 Payment Card Transactions Payment Card Transactions is the only case discrep- ancy.
